titleStmt.title: Part of ye 08. 7th 08. Epistle of the
first Book of Horace
imitated

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Harley, the Nation's great Support,
Returning home one day from Court,
(His Mind with publick Care possess't,
All Europe's business in His breast)
Observ'd a Parson near Whitehall
Cheapning old Authors on a Stall.
The Priest was pretty well in case,
And shew'd some Humour in his Face;
Look'd with an easy careless Mien,
A Perfect Stranger to the Spleen;
Of Size that might a Pulpit fill
But more inclining to sit still.
My Lord, who (if a Man may say't)
Love's mischief better than his Meat,
Was now dispos'd to crack a Iest;
And bid friend Lewis go in quest
(This Lewis is a cunning Shaver
And very much in Harley's favour)
In quest who might this Parson be
What was his Name, of what degree;
If possible to learn his Story,
And whether he were Whig or Tory.Lewis his Patron's Humour know's;
Away upon his Errand goes,
And quickly did the matter sift
Found out that it was Dṛ S──t:
A Clergyman of speciall Note,
For shunning those of his own Coat,
Which made his Brethren of the Gown
Take care betimes to run him down:
No Libertine, nor Over-nice,
Addicted to no sort of Vice;
Went where he pleas'd, said what he thought,
Not rich, but ow'd no Man a Groat;
In state Opinions a-la Mode,
He hated Wh--n like a Toad;
Had giv'n the Faction many a wound
And libell'd all the Iunto round;
Kept Company with Men of Wit,
Who often father'd what he writ;
His works were hawk'd in ev'ry street,
But seldom rose above a sheet:
Of late indeed the Paper-Stamp
Did very much his Genius cramp:
And, since he could not spend his Fire
He now intended to retire.Said Harley, I desire to know
From his own Mouth, if this be so.
Step to the Doctour straight, and say,
I'd have him dine with me to day.
S──t seem'd to wonder what he meant,
Nor would beleive my Lord had sent;
So never offer'd once to stir,
But coldly said, Yṛ Servant, Sir.
Does he refuse me, (Harley cry'd)?
He does, with Insolence & pride.Some few days after, Harley spies
The Doctour fastend by the Eyes
At Charing-cross among the Rout,
Where painted Monsters are hung out.
He pull'd the string and stop't his Coach,
Beck'ning the Doctour to approach.S──t who could neither fly nor hide,
Came sneaking to the Chariot side,
And offer'd many a lame excuse;
“He never meant the least Abuse──
“My Lord──The Honour you design'd──
“Extreamly proud──but I had din'd──
“I'm sure I never should neglect──
“No Man alive has more respect──
Well I shall think of that no more,
If you'l be sure to come at four.The Doctour now obeys the Summons,
Like's both his Company and Commons;
Display's his Talent, sits till ten,
Next day invited, come's agen:
Soon grows Domestick, seldom fail's
Either at Mornings or a Meals:
Came early, and departed late;
In short the Gudgeon took the Bait.
My Lord wou'd carry on the Iest,
And down to Windsor take's his Guest.
S──much admire's the place and Air
And long's to be a Canon there;
In summer round the Park to ride,
In Winter──never to reside.
A Canon! That's a place too mean:
No, Doctour, You shall be a Dean;
Two dozen Canons round yṛ stall,
And You the Tyrant o're them all:
You need but cross the Irish Seas,
To live in Plenty, Power and Ease.Poor S──t departs, and what is worse
With borrow'd Mony in his Purse;
Travel's at least an hundred Leagues
And suffer's numberless Fatigues.Suppose him now a Dean compleat,
Devoutly lolling in his Seat;
The Silver Virge with decent Pride,
Stuck underneath his Cushion-side:
Suppose him gone through all Vexations,
Patents, Installments, Abjurations,
First-fruits & Tenths, and Chapter-Treats,
Dues, Payments, Fees, Demands and Cheats,
(The wicked Layity's contriving
To hinder Clergymen from thriving);
Now all the Doctour's Mony's spent,
His Tenants wrong him in his Rent;
The Farmers, spitefully combin'd,
Force him to take his Tyths in kind;
And <«FN1·>The Dean's 1crop·gent, a Frenchman.ed Parvisol discount's Arrears,</«FN1·>
By Bills for Taxes and Repairs.Poor S──t with all his losses vext,
Not knowing where to turn him next;
Above a thousand Pounds in Debt,
Take's Horse and in a mighty Fret,
Rides Day and Night at such a Rate,
He soon arrive's at Harley's Gate;
But was so dirty, pale and thin,
Old Read wou'd hardly let him in.Said Harley; welcome Reverend Dean!
What make's Yṛ Worship look so lean?
Why sure You won't appear in Town
In that old Wig and rusty Gown!
I doubt Your Heart is set on Pelf
So much, that You neglect Yṛ self.
What! I suppose now stocks are high,
You've some good purchace in Yṛ Eye;
Or is Your Mony out at Use?──Truce, good My Lord, I beg a Truce!
The Doctour in a Passion cryed;
Your Raillery is misapplied:
I have experience dearly bought;
You know I am not worth a Groat:
But You resolv'd to have yṛ Iest,
And t'was a Folly to contest:
Then since You now have done Your worst,
Pray leave me, where You found me first.
Dṛ Swift.170-103M
